reviews.author: mi0304
reviews.comment_content:
Following from MATH1013 L01, MATH1014 L01 covers 6 chapters:
Chapter 5 Integration I - Basics
Chapter 6 Integration II - Techniques
Chapter 7 Geometry
Chapter 8 Sequences
Chapter 9 Infinite Series
Chapter 10 Taylor Series and Fourier Series
reviews.comment_teaching:
Lectures: Prof. IP taught in a good way that it was easy for students to catch up, and he is willing to answer questions. You can skip any lecture as he provided helpful recordings. The attendance was not recorded.

Tutorial: This is very helpful. The tutor was friendly and he responded to your questions in time.
reviews.comment_grading:
20% - Assignment (Full mark for each hw is 60, 10 times overall, abandon one of the lowest mark)
10-40% - Midterm (Automatically weighed at the end of the semester)
40-70% - Final

The professor published this on canvas at the beginning of the semester:
"Letter grades will be assigned depending on overall performance.
Obtaining a total point of 95% or above will guarantee an A+.
Obtaining a total point of 80% or above will guarantee an A-range.
Obtaining a total point of 60% or above will guarantee a B-range.
Obtaining a total point of 30% or above will guarantee a passing grade."
But he did not really follow this, because no one got that high. Finally, people who got over 80% got A+, over 72% was A, over 65% was A-.
reviews.comment_workload:
Assignment: No webwork but one written homework every week. This is much easier than MATH1024 and MATH1023, but I think it would be harder than WebWork.

The midterm only covered less than two chapters, which was manageable, but the final covered more. But fortunately, professor decided to not test too much on Geometry and Fourier Series, only some true/false questions included those contents. If you passed MATH1023, the content covered after midterm would not be that difficult, since lots of stuff were repetitive.

reviews.author: Mubin
reviews.comment_content:
L01 section is harder than other L02-11 sections and easier than MATH 1024 and it is specifically designed for potential Math Majors. While the main content is similar to other sections, L01 section emphasizes conceptual understanding and will have a lot of proof writings.
If you enroll in other sections, you may find it harder to transit into second-year math courses, especially MATH 2033 - Mathematical Analysis, which is a required course for Math majors, and it requires a strong logical mindset and solid conceptual understanding of single-variable calculus.


(Note that, unlike other sections, L01 section starts from the beginning of integration.)

Integration: Riemann Integrations, Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, Integration Techniques, Reduction Formula, Improper Integrals.
Geometry: Vectors, Parametric Equation, Polar Coordinates, Volume.
Sequence and Infinite series: Convergence Tests, Power series, Taylor Series, Fourier Series.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Ivan's teaching pace is always like watching a video at 1.5x speed. To grasp all the content, it's better to study the lecture notes before attending the lectures. It will also be great if you watch the recording of the lecture again after attending the lecture in person.
reviews.comment_workload:
You have to solve a lot of problems. You have to dedicate a lot of time to that. Solve ALL the problems of Calculus, Early Transcendentals on Classviva. Make sure you keep in mind the different type of problems available there. Some of them will be trivial, harder problems will come in handy. Make sure you solve the Exercise problems of Lecture Notes, Worksheet Problems and go through the tutorial notes.

Finally, DO NOT be a deadline fighter!

reviews.author: IDIOTHAHAHA
reviews.title: Useful content but trash lecturer trash TA
reviews.comment_content: The content are super difficult but the lecturer always skip some critical concepts and assume that you know them.
reviews.comment_teaching:
After seeing some people said Ye Guibo was a decent lecturer, I enrolled in her session. However, I found that her lectures notes are very messy and hard to read because every page is full of words.

Besides, I think I found some mistakes in her lecture notes so I sent email to ask all 3 TAs of L9 because Ye Guibo said she never answer email on Sunday and Saturday. Still no one reply my email after one week. What would you feel when you spend a lot of time on setting query and composing emails but the receiver ignore them. I don't really care whether they are strong or not but I care about their attitude. But I guess one male TA of L9 is decent and acceptible because he tried hard to answer my questions in tutorial class T9A. Although I might not fully understand some concepts, I still appreciate his efforts.

Also, Ye Guibo's accent is bad. For example, in last few lectures I finally figure out that "offer-we-are-say" is "obviously". So pay attention to it.

Another thing is that she doesn't want to run the risk of being late on another class so she would only answer you very briefly if you ask her questions right after class in that situation.

In tutorial class, most people just attend the first one to see whether the TA are good or not and whether attendance would be taken or not. After that, there can be no one in the classroom except the TA and you (if you attend).
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm: 35%
Final: 55%
HW: 10%
because many people in the below review said that the grading is bad, I guess it will probably remain bad so I give a E. This is an induction, right?
reviews.comment_workload:
9 compulsory homework on webwork. Since you can try unlimited times, you would eventually do them all correct unless you don't have enough time.
You also need to spend a lot of time to digest the lecture notes because as I say, Ye Guibo's lecture notes are actually bad.

In order to integrate," I knew I was in for a very awful time when I heard that in the first class.

reviews.author: _Wh.M
reviews.comment_content:
The content includes:
1. Integration (by part)
2. Volume (disk method, shell method)
3. Work Done
4. Plane Coordinate (arc length, surface area)
5. Polar Coordinate (length, area)
----- midterm exam -----
6. Numerical Integration (Trapezium, Mid-point, Simpson)
7. Improper Integration
8. Sequence and series*
(convergence, epsilon-delta, integral test, limit convergent test, root test, alternating series test)
9. Power Series and Taylor Series* (radius of convergence, Maclaurin expansion)
(the most difficult topic I think)
10. Vectors (dot product, cross product,

The topics with * are important topics (tested a lot in the final exam)

The content is really difficult. The syllabus of DSE M2 only covers a very small part (by part, disk method) of the content of this course. Some of the topics like Reimann sum in MATH 1013 can be seen in this course.
reviews.comment_teaching: I think TA is helpful and the in-class exercise helped me to build a better understanding on the content being taught in the lectures.
reviews.comment_grading:
Tutorial in-class worksheets (20%)
Midterm Exam (25%)
Final Exam (55%)

My mark:
tutorial in-class worksheets - missed four tutorials
Strongly recommend to attend all the tutorials. Get the easy marks and solidify your understanding.

midterm - 75/80
(mean: 37.4 sd: 19.51)

final - 60/100
(mean: 30.02 sd: 15.09)

The midterm exam is okay, but the final exam is terribly difficult.

Final grade: A
reviews.comment_workload:
Except the midterm and final exam, we have to finish a in-class worksheet once a week in the tutorial session. There is a total of 12 tutorial classworks, and the professor will drop the three worksheets with the lowest marks.

We are asked to do at least two questions on the worksheets to obtain full marks. The TA will give full marks even though the answer is not correct or incomplete.

I think the workload is ok, but I am too lazy to attend the tutorials, so I would give a C.

reviews.author: oscargu
reviews.comment_content:
Topics include applications of definite integral, improper integrals, vectors, curves and parametric equations, modeling with differential equations, solving simple differential equations, infinite sequences and series, power series and Taylor series.

For the integrals, its like more on the high school stuff.
For the curves, the course will teach you to calculate the length and area etc.
Some concepts and usage of the series will also be included.
reviews.comment_teaching: The teaching is not really good. Pace is a bit slow and the spoken English could be more fluent, or else it may affect the learning.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading
75% Final
25% Assignment

No mid-term

The online assignment is basically once per topic (1-2 weeks)
You can submit unlimited times until you are satisfied with your score (try get full score on each assignment, it will be helpful)
Read the notes and keep the concepts clear is ok, also you can do some exercise or review the questions in assignments if you have time.

Assignment (100%)
Final (92%)
Grade: A
(Overall grade >= 95% can get A+, what a pity)
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is not high, just one assignment per 1-2 weeks. Each assignment contains 8-15 questions, including MC and short questions.
Other than that, you may need study harder near final.

reviews.author: 神仙1號
reviews.title: Youtube videos helped me a lot.
reviews.comment_content:
Week 1

Review of definite integrals and the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus. (4.2, 4.3)

Week 2

Substitution Method (4.4) Integrating by parts (4.5)

Week 3

Trigonometric integrals, and the method of partial fractions (4.6)

Week 4

Numerical integration (4.7) Improper integrals (4.8)

Week 5

Areas between curves (5.1) Volumes by slicing (5.2)

Week 6

Volume by cylindrical shells (5.2) Arc lengths and surface areas (5.3, 5.4)

Week 7

Polar coordinates and calculus (5.5) Work (5.7)

Week 8

Infinite sequences and series (6.1, 6.2) Integral test (6.3)

Week 9

Comparison tests (6.4) Alternating series (6.5)

Week 10

Absolute and conditional convergence (6.5) Taylor and Maclaurin series (7.1, 7.2) Representation of functions as power series (7.2)

Week 11

Interval of convergence of a power series (7.3) Applications of Taylor polynomials (7.4)

Week 12

Three dimensional coordinate systems, Vectors

Week 13

Dot product, Cross product
reviews.comment_teaching:
I had only attended the first lecture in the whole semester because I found watching youtube videos were more efficient for me to learn. I suggest The Organic Chemistry Tutor because he explained the concept well with various examples. Despite the fact that he don't explain how the formulae come, I find it is enough for me to get a mark close to the mean.

If I had learnt how the formulae are derived, I would have had more understanding on those topics.
reviews.comment_grading:
I don't know why other students said the grading of this course is good. If you get a mean mark, you may get a C+.

The exam is not hard because it contains all mc questions. Not figuring out an answer, you can choose one of the choices. If you are lucky enough, you may get all correct although you don't know what exactly the answers are.

Remember to read through the instructions of the exam, which will be sent to you via email.
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload is not heavy. There is around 1 assignment per week on Classviva website . Just finish the assignments and you will get a basic understanding on those topics.

I got some help from the UST Maths centre. I found it was quite useful when I got stuck in a question for a long time and could not find the answers to the questions on the internet.

Past midterm paper and final paper will be uploaded to a website which you can find it in the email from the instructor when the exam is approaching.

reviews.author: line
reviews.title: Calculus II
reviews.comment_content:
Velocity and net change, area of a region between curves, volume by slicing and cylindrical shells.
• Length of curves, surface area, and work.
• Integration by parts, trigonometric integrals, trigonometric substitutions, polar coordinates and calculus,
partial fractions.
• Numerical integration, improper integrals.
• Sequences and infinite series, divergence and integral, ratio, root and comparison tests, alternating series.
• Taylor polynomials, power series and Taylor series.
• Vectors in two and three dimensions, dot products, cross products.

If you study M2 in HKDSE, congratulations, you have finish  over 75% of the course. The only thing left for you is Series and sequence

EXAM: midterm, 10 MC, 2 long question; final exam, online 20 MC

Textbook: J. Stewart, “Calculus” , no comment

If you got problems, go to Math Support Centre (MSC), very useful and helpful

Just remember it is normal to get a bad result in this course, don't get frustrated is the only thing important to get a better grade.
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload is low, only WebWorks and optional bonus quizzes after MT. The workload can be high if you dig deep into the knowledge and strive for a A grade.

Tutorials don't count attendance, so you can skip all the classes for this course if you are confident enough.

Integration techniques
Integration by parts, substitution , parital
Polar coordinate

If BDSM is your thing, then you'll enjoy this. You get to learn all sorts of ways to torture yourself you didn't even know existed!!! From the light and kinky stuff like volumes of revolution to the hardcore and masochistic stuff like series expansions and partial fractions expansions.

Okay, in all seriousness, it's Calculus 2 for those who follow the US curriculum. You learn integration techniques for the first half then you go on to learning series, sequences etc in the second half. I'm sure it's useful stuff, but still hard none the less.

This course will not be too difficult if you have studied M2 in DSE. The vector part of this course is no where near as hard as that in DSE. reviews.author: ustiong
reviews.comment_content:
about integration:
- applications: area, arc length, volume , surface area, work done, polar coordinates and calculus
- techniques: integration by parts, reduction formula, trigonometric substitution, partial fractions
- Approximating integrals: mid-point rule, trapezoidal rule, Simpson's rule
- Improper integral: test for convergence, comparison theorem

Series:
- limit of infinite sequence
- sum of infinite series
- basic example of series: geometric, harmonic series, p-series
- tests for convergence: divergent test, integral test, comparison test, limit comparison test, ratio & root test, alternating series test
- Power series, Taylor and Maclaurin Series

Vectors:
just some basic things that you've learnt in M2 such as dot product, cross product, triple scalar product, orthogonal projection and volume of parallelepiped

reviews.author: chpoonag
reviews.comment_content:
- knowledge in Math 1013
- volume (shell method and disc method)
- work (physics)
- average value of a function, arc length, area of a surface of revolution
- integration by parts, trigonometric integrals, trigonometric substitution
- polar coordinates and calculus
- partial fraction
- approximation integration, improper integrals
- infinite sequences and series, integral test, comparison test, alternating test, absolute convergence, ratio and root tests
- power series, representation of functions as power series, Taylor and Maclaurin series, application of Taylor polynomials
- 2 and 3 dimensional coordinate systems, vectors, dot and cross product

In the final exam, the main focus is on the series and sequence. Requirements of and conclusion given by each test (for convergence or divergence of a series, eg Comparison Test, Alt. Series Test, ...) should be RECITED clearly. It is also reminded that if requirements of a test are not completely satisfied, usually no conclusion can be drawn.

There is a distinct teaching and exam style for those lectures taught by Dr Hu Jishan. His exam and test are different from others in that they focus on proofs whereas others focus on application matters.

It could be a great advantage if you took M2 in college.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Dr Yang's teaching a fair. His voice is without intonation, which could make you fall asleep. He follows what is taught in the textbook, page by page. It may be a good thing as he would then never go off-topic. You may ask him questions whatever you have come up with just after the lecture.

Mr Fan is a patient and responsive TA, despite few students' attendance of tutorial class. You can ask him after tutorial class, or by email. There was once just some hours before the exam that he replied to my email only 6 minutes after the email was sent to him.
reviews.comment_grading:
Absolute grading.
15% homework
35% midterm
50% final
+ 8% bonus quizzes (4 in total)

Note: F < 40% < D < 50% < C-/+ < 65% < B-/+ < 85% < A-/+

Long questions in the exam paper is pretty akin to the sample paper (ie the paper of previous year)

~My performance~
Homework: 15/15
Midterm: 90/100 (4 marks gained after paper checking)
Final: 97/100
Grade: A+

**Always check paper and asked for any possible marks for correct methods.
reviews.comment_workload:
Small workload. A total of 10 WeBWork assignments, usually 1 per week or a bit longer than a week, contingent on the progress of teaching. You have unlimited times of attempts for each questions.

Like the previous year, due to too high percentage of students getting F (40%) in the midterm, 4 bonus quizzes which accounts for a total of an EXTRA 8% in the final total score would be done in maths support centre. It is reminded that sample paper will be provided in the maths support centre without answers, but you can ask the tutors there if you wish. Those sample papers are really helpful as they were derived from the actual papers we did and hence they were very similar to the actual ones.

reviews.comment_teaching:

reviews.comment_grading:
Hell mode, but miracle for me (so I gave a B)

Tutorial (20%) graded by effort, drop 3 lowest marks, so most people get full score I think
Mid-term (25%) not so hard, open-book and calculator (even the last question was similar to the tutorial question, so you could just copy and paste)
Final (55%) hell mode, open-book, and no calculator allowed (multiple choices were about integration and long questions included infinite series and sequences) much more questions than the past paper

Midterm: Mean 37.4/80, SD 19.51
Final: Mean 30.02/100 (HELL MODE), SD 15.09
Total Score: Mean 45.35/100 SD 15.37

My Score:
Midterm: 80
Final: 75
Total: 86.25
Letter Grade: A+ (Miracle for me, I thought I would get an A)

Professor Chiang said he used absolute grading, but maybe with 10 points deducted from the normal absolute grading scheme. Mean is C and 1.2~1.3 SD above mean is B+

reviews.author: taylorswift
reviews.title: If you get TK, you're 100% on your own (aka Youtube tutorials)
reviews.comment_content:
Disclaimer: SBM student with below-average 'math sense' (数学感; not sure how to word sorry!), so bear in mind that your experiences may differ from mine!

An interesting range of content covered, some more useful than others. Not much of a math person but I can definitely see how it would fascinate some :)

Biggest issue with content is the allocation of time for each section and how it was delivered. Will elaborate on both in 'Teaching'.

DO ALL PASTPAPERS YOU CAN FIND. CLASSVIVA QUESTIONS ARE
reviews.comment_teaching:
Disclaimer: I am in a good mood today, this review is likely biased in TK's favor. (On a regular day, will give him F)

Teaching Style:
TK likes to go into a lot of theory not useful for exam. He also enjoys making up questions on the spot that he cannot solve without making 2+ mistakes. Very hard to follow and connect theory/proofs to questions solved, especially as they are not similar to exam or homework style questions and he does not explain thought process before solving + always makes mistakes.
Often, he just explains and derives the origins of each formula/shortcut mathematically but allocates very little time to
how and when to use each formula.

Time:
Spent too much time re-capping 1013/high school content that we were left with 3 lessons before finals for the final topic. TK decided to not test on final topic but notified everyone with 1 week before the exam. He also kept teaching the final topic and did not go over previous content at all (in SBM it is common for professors to have 1-2 revision lessons to refresh our minds before finals season)

TK's unpreparedness in lessons meant that he did a lot of improv. He makes up questions on the spot and sometimes decides halfway through solving it that it is too tedious and changes the question - but doesn't demonstrate how to solve it! (He only gave a general/theoretical explanation). He also makes a lot of mistakes that students have to point out. Would hence recommend rewatching recordings instead of joining live.
To buy time for improv, he writes down everything he says on his iPad. Whereas TAs have prepared condensed, no BS version of curriculum and some even have handwritten scans of questions, solutions, diagrams etc (like PPT style teaching) and explain things more thoroughly. Highly recommend watching tutorials (fortunate for me, zoom Uni meant I had access to all TA tutorials in 2 lectures so I could choose the one that suited me most)
reviews.comment_grading:
General performance in midterm so poor that a grading scheme was introduced MIDTERM(35%) + FINAL(55%) and purely FINAL(90%) grades, grade is best of 2.

Fair grading by UST standards, but less generous than other SBM courses. 62.97% mean, got B for 77.5%
reviews.comment_workload:
Homeworks per subject section on Classviva. Knowledge required is approx 2 weeks behind the teaching schedule, so can finish even if you are behind on lessons.

Can be tricky but not unreasonable. Aim for 100% because unlimited tries + ample time = insanely high mean

Limit
Taylor and Maclaurin Expansion
Series
Vectors (Cancelled in Final)

reviews.comment_teaching: Prof Hu is a very interesting instructor. He tries to explain every single thing in class, which sounds nice but always leads to very slow progress. What is terrible about him is that he doesn't give lecture notes, he just write on tha blackboard.

My score: Midterm:81 Final:95 Homework:88.89%(I forgot 1 >>sad)
overall:94.39 A+

reviews.author: Albertus
reviews.title: Self Study All Over Again
reviews.comment_content: For online course, there are no attendance taken. This course covers integration, application of integration, infinite sequence and series, and series of function. Materials can be studied from the book and various websites on the internet.
reviews.comment_teaching: Cannot really say much, since only 3 lectures attended (first 2 lectures and the very final one). The number of participants are really low and the professor has a very thick Chinese accent, making him hard to understand.
reviews.comment_grading:
25% Homework
75% Finals

The grading is truly harsh. The homework is very doable and helpful to the overall grades since it is unlimited trials. However the final exam is truly despicable. A very tight time and long questions are not a good combination. The finals consists of 25 multiple questions divided to 3 parts.
reviews.comment_workload: The work load mostly come from the constant classviva homework and self studying the materials. The classviva homework has unlimited trials, thus you can just attempt until you get 100. Online tools such as derivative calculator makes it really possible to achieve it. It is easier compared to MATH1013 since the basic of this course is mostly taken from that specific course.

reviews.author: postexampls

reviews.comment_content:
The content is pretty much a continuation of MATH1013, and if you took M2 DSE, you might be familiar with some of the stuff here.

CONTENT:
Review of definite integrals and the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus.

Integration by parts, trigonometric integrals, trigonometric substitutions, partial fractions, polar coordinates and calculus.

Numerical integration, improper integrals.

Area of a region between curves, volume by slicing and cylindrical shells.

Length of curves, surface area, work, average value of a function.

Sequences and infinite series, divergence and integral, ratio, root and comparison tests, alternating series.

Taylor polynomials, power series and Taylor series.

Vectors in two and three dimensions, dot products, cross products. (WAS NOT INCLUDED IN FINAL EXAM THIS TERM)

reviews.comment_content: 系mid-term之前的內容大概都系integration，比如用integration計面積同體積，長度，workdone等，仲有更多既integration既方法，比如integration by part，partial fraction呢的，mid-term之後就比較關limit事多的，比如integration by part, sequence, series, 最後仲有少少vector 同matrix，但唔算太多。個人來講，以我讀1012既人來講，我覺得1014比1012或1013易一的，但後面series同sequence就比較需要時間去理解。
reviews.comment_teaching: JIN，Tianling我覺得系所有math 1014 professor入面教得最好果個。佢系堂上會用佢部iPad Pro將的內容一個一個寫出來再解釋比我地聽，入面仲有的圖幫你理解。的notes之後都會擺上canvas。mid-term同exam之前仲會同我地一題一題講的sample paper。可能都因為甘所以佢教既班個mean比其他班要高出十幾二十分。唯一唔好就系佢上堂會點人回答問題。tutorial我本身果個教得唔好，因此我走左去sit Phyllis的堂，佢講得比較清楚，最緊要系佢仲會比埋彩色印刷既notes附加Zeta Chan的練習。的notes上面都有的解釋同練習，好多人都會來sit佢的堂，差唔多有一半人系甘。但都因為講得太仔細所以進度嚴重落後，令我地仲要系study break加多幾堂。

reviews.author: yu006493
reviews.comment_content:
Week 1 Review of definite integrals and the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, area between curves, volumes by cross-sections.
Week 2 Volumes by cylindrical shells, work.
Week 3 Average value of a function, arc length, area of a surface of revolution.
Week 4 Integration by parts, trigonometric integrals.
Week 5 Trigonometric substitution, polar coordinates and calculus.
Week 6 Partial fractions, summary of integration techniques.
Week 7 Approximation integration, improper integrals.
Week 8 Infinite sequences and series, integral test.
Week 9 Comparison tests, alternating series, absolute convergence, ratio and root tests
Week 10 Power series, representation of functions as power series.
Week 11 Taylor and Maclaurin series, applications of Taylor polynomials, two and three-dimensional coordinate systems, vectors.
Week 12 Dot product.
Week 13 Cross product.

The correlation between each weeks topic is not big, you can still able understand the content even if you didn't catch up the previous lecture.

I don't like this course because this course emphasizes computation more than proof/understanding, in mid-term you just have to compute lots of definite integrals again and again and calculator is not allowed. You need to be fast and careful.
reviews.comment_teaching: There are 11 sections, some lecturers are good some are bad. I didn't found my tutorial section is useful so I skipped most of them.
reviews.comment_grading:
My Overall Percentage: 79%
Mean percentage of the course: 69%
Grade: B
There are 4 bonus quizzes after midterm you can get 108%at max
you can get A range >=85%
I think if you pay effort and do exercise you can get A range
reviews.comment_workload:
You only need to do webwork every week.
1/3 of the content is taught in M2 therefore the workload is not that big.
Even you start studying before exam you can still to do ok in the exam.

reviews.title: fair grade
reviews.comment_content:
MId-term syllabus:
(Integration + polar)
integration include:
area between curve
work
integration by part
trigo integral
trigo substitution
integration by partial fraction
approximation integration
improper integral

Polar include:
Polar graph (area, length)
-------------------------------------------------------
After mid-term (Sequence & series + vector)
Sequence & series include:
infinite series, integral test, alternating series, comparison test, absolute convergence, ratio and root test, power series, taylor and maclaurin series)

vector: find component of "A" vector on "B" vector, projection of "A" on "B"

basically, the 2 big big big topics are Integration and Sequence & series. For integration problem, u need to learn how to use multiple strategy/technique to solve it.

For exam, Polar and vector only constitute around 10% of the mark.

Mid-term content

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Final Exam Content (Non-cumulative)
10.1 Curves Defined by Parametric Equations
• 10.2 Calculus with Parametric Curves
• 10.3 Polar Coordinates
• 10.4 Areas and Lengths in Polar Coordinates
• 11.1 Sequences
• 11.2 Series
• 11.3 The Integral Test and Estimates of Sums
• 11.4 The Comparison Tests
• 11.5 Alternating Series
• 11.6 Absolute Convergence and the Ratio and Root Tests
• 11.7 Strategy for Testing Series
• 11.8 Power Series
• 11.9 Representations of Functions as Power Series

6. “Estimates of Sums” will not be in the final examination.

reviews.author: abcbca
reviews.title: Frustrating Math course.
reviews.comment_content:
It's a consecutive math course of MATH1013. The content of this course mainly include 5 general topics:

(1) Basic Knowledge of Integration
Substantial content is included in M2.
- Integration of simple functions
- Integration by Substitution
- Integration by Parts
- Trigonometry + Integration

New Concept:
- Displacement, Velocity, Acceleration
- Distance travelled by particle
- Future Value and Net Change

(2) Application of Integration
Half of the content is covered by M2, but the exam question can be extremely difficult without using calculator.
- Area between curves
- Volume of solid by revolving around axis/line i.e. Disk/Shell method

New concepts:
- Slicing Method
- Arc Length of a curve
- Surface Area of the solid generated by revolving around axis
- Hooke's Law
- Density and Work
- Polar Coordinates and Calculus
- Area bounded by curves and Arc length of curves in Polar Coordinates
- Partial Fractions and Integration
- Estimation for the value of Finite Integration
- Improper Integrals

(3) Sequence and Series
Important content:
- Limit of a sequence
- Partial Sum, Sum of Series
- Geometric Series
- p-Series
- 8 Convergence Test of Series

(4) Application of Series
- Taylor/Maclaurin polynomials
- Binomial polynomials
- Remainder Theorem of Taylor Series

(5) Vectors
All concepts are covered by M2.

Personally, I think the most difficult part of the course is Work and Comparison Test.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I skipped all lessons and tutorials.

I studied hard on half of all lecture notes on Canvas, especially Work, Sequence and Series.

Notes of Professor Zhang are treasures. If you deliberately revise on all the notes, you should obtain a clear concept.

Remember that all proves will not be examined.
reviews.comment_grading:
12% Webwork
33% Midterm
55% Final
5% 4 optional Quizzes provided by MSC computers

Midterm
Mean=~64 SD=~15
Final
Mean=~58 SD=~20
Overall ~85% may be the requirement of attaining A range.

Actually, if you want to get a normal/good grade, the quizzes must be done as almost everyone would choose to do it and get (nearly) full marks. Don't consider the quizzes as a tool to redress for the marks in your exam.
reviews.comment_workload:
If you haven't taken M2 as your elective in secondary school, you must pay double efforts to get a better grade as 50% of the course content is bounded in the syllabus of M2, including around 70% of the Integration topics and all Vector topics. You must pay more efforts to it as a student who has studied M2 may not even be able to handle this course easily.

If you didn't study anything about Physics in secondary school, make sure you've understood and prepared for the questions about Works under the Integration topic. It is quite likely to appear in Mid-term and Final exams.

If you've studied M2 in secondary school, Congratulations!
You have relatively less workload than others, but you've to pay extra attention to Convergence tests for Series as many students failed to understand and apply in the exam questions. The series to be tested in those questions can be unimaginable.

reviews.comment_teaching: Neat notes, with colorful annotations and graphs, plenty of examples. Explained details in lectures quite clearly, but sometime still need to Google. She replied email usually in 2 days.

reviews.author: Atom
reviews.title: Good grades for students with decent math abilities
reviews.comment_content:
Integration techniques: (trigonometric) substitution, integration by parts, reduction formulae
Arc length, surface area and volume of revolution of curves
Polar coordinates (arc length and area under polar curves)
Sequences and series (their limits, test for convergence/divergence)
Vectors (not in exams this semester)

Basically first half of the course is M2 stuff, second half just extends the concepts by a little bit. People with decent math abilities/foundation won't find this course difficult (also recommend watching some math videos on YouTube, helps with your understanding a lot since they explain concepts clearly, sometimes with intuitive visualizations). Also doing exercises is important in learning math, don't expect you can do nothing and master a math concept (but there is no need to spam them, refer to workload section).
reviews.comment_teaching:
Ye Guibo has tidy hand-written lecture notes (although sometimes there are mistakes, just ask her to clarify) with good visualizations (especially in arc lengths, areas, volumes, and polar plots). The steps are clear and understandable.
However, she has a strong mainland English accent so those who cannot accept such accent may consider just referring to her lecture notes lol (I attended most lectures, she sometimes encourages students to understand concepts, although only few people attended lectures).
As for tutorials, I attended the first and never attended the subsequent ones. The TA gave me a bad impression but I guess it depends on your math abilities. I would say tutorials are a way to do exercises to familiarize yourself with the math concepts so if you feel unclear you can attend.
reviews.comment_grading:
Absolute grading (but this semester the cut-off lines are slightly lowered)
- 10% WebWork
- 35% Mid-term
- 55% Final
Mid-term and final has mean ~60, sd ~20 as usual

Personal comments:
A+ cut-off is 92.5 this semester which I personally think is more than acceptable
Mid-term is quite short on time and the long questions actually don't weigh that much so just being careful in MCs can yield good marks
Final gives a lot of time, so check every question to eliminate careless mistakes

Overall, grading is good if you understand the concepts and have done some practice.
reviews.comment_workload:
- 10 short WebWork assignments with plenty of time to finish (a few weeks)
- And that's all :)
Of course if you want to master the concepts, there are some additional questions in CANVAS page that you can do for study/revision. I did not do all of them, just spent 2 hours doing selected questions, and another <10 hours for past paper. The workload is actually very light for people who are decent in math.
It is not that difficult to catch up if you feel the content is difficult. Just spend some time watching YouTube videos, asking professors/classmates, and doing exercises and you will do great.

reviews.author: scyeung

reviews.comment_content: The content is equivalent to CalcII though easier than some famous institutions.

reviews.comment_grading:
MT: 90
Final: 97
Total: ~94
Grade: A+
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is very light. Problems in webwork can prepare you for finals.
I know many students complain about the difficulty of the exam. But these complaints are not justified. One problem appearing in midterm draws a lot of controversy, however, when I give the problem to F.5 students who are studying M.2. Many students are able to get a decent mark on the question. This proves that the derivations required in this problem are not outrageously difficult. Such problems also appear in previous finals. The problem this year isn't particularly difficult.

reviews.author: TO Junheng
reviews.title: Not so Easy as MATH 1013
reviews.comment_content:
This course is not thought to be so easy as MATH1013. If you want a decent grade, you need to work on it.

The content mainly covers integration techniques, applications of integration, improper integrals, sequence, and series.

Owing to the special arrangement of the summer version MATH 1014, no lecture is given. You are supposed to show up in the morning classes and afternoon quizzes regularly, about three times a week. Before classes, you need to go through canvas materials which include important lecture concepts and some practice problems.

During the class, you are supposed to finish class problem sets on time. If you have any questions, you can feel free to reach TAs or T.K. Lam. During the quizzes, there should be five to six problems including fillings and MCs for you to solve. They are easier than the questions you meet in the morning.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The canvas materials are clear and concise, you can grasp ideas in it easily.

T.K. Lam replies emails selectively, but he never misses important emails.

TAs answer questions patiently. You can feel free to raise questions in either Cantonese or English. (I don't know if Putonghua works, cuz I didn't do that qwq)
reviews.comment_grading:
Scheme:
20%classwork + 20% quizzes + 60% final

Grading is fair and much more lenient than the spring one.

Basically it is absolute grading, but T.K. lowered cutoffs so that every got a better grade.

Cutoffs:
A+/A/A- : 82/88/94
B+/B/B- > 66/74/82
C+/C/C- > 47/58/66

My total is approximately 99 and yields an A+.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is somewhat big. You need to go through all the materials to secure a good grade. It is also not feasible to take an internship with this course concurring.

reviews.author: Tim Ho
reviews.title: Good course
reviews.comment_content:
I get A+.

This course mainly focuses on integration, series, and vectors. In my opinion, they are not as difficult as some might think, as long as you do lots of exercise.

I believe many who will take this course are year 1 students. Just finishing DSE and entering the relaxing environment of the university, you may tend to finish the homework only, rather than further exploring problems from the system that the course provides, or even from other textbooks, like Thomas Calculus, or other sources.

I sincerely recommend you solve more problems to ensure you understand the teaching content. Homework problems are very good, but not enough, if you want to get a higher grade.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor's teaching is boring, but his notes are clear and well understandable. So after the midterm, I only learn from his look instead of his lecture.
reviews.comment_grading: This course is not a good grading course. It is not easy to get a high grade. Other than its teaching material, including lecture notes and homework, you need to find other materials to help your learning. I got Thomas Calculus to have me extra explanations on the theories and a great question bank. It really takes time. However, it is worthwhile because the course is very important. I guess you will not choose this course because of grading.
reviews.comment_workload: The basic workload is not heavy. Around 1-2 weeks there will a homework which take you roughly 3 hours. However, if you want to learn better, you should find more materials by yourself. In that scenario, the workload depends on what you want to achieve. For me, I paid extra 5-10 hours a week.

reviews.author: Wahoo
reviews.title: Quite easy and leng grade course
reviews.comment_content:
Integration techniques: trigonometric substitution, integration by parts, partial fractions, numerical integration and improper integrals.
Applications of integrals: area between curves, volume, arc lengths, surface area, and work done.
Parametric equations and polar coordinates. Area.
Infinite sequences and series. Geometric series, alternating series, harmonic series, all those convergence divergence tests, power series, and Taylor and Maclaurin series.
Vectors (cancelled for final exam)

Basically just M2 things. Not hard if you have a good background.
Revising all contents in tutorial notes would be enough for examinations.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Don't expect the professor would teach you anything. Skipped all lectures after the first one.

TA would give a more detailed explanation to you, so make sure to watch tutorial videos before examinations, revise tutorial notes, and do past papers to be familiar with question types if you want to get a good grade in this course.

Self-learning is much better than wasting an hour in lectures. Personally, I did 5 past papers for midterm and final, eventually I got A-
reviews.comment_grading:
Only this term have 2 grading scheme, the higher score one would be adopted
Scheme 1: 10% Classviva + 35% Midterm + 55% Final
Scheme 2: 10% Classviva + 90% final

Classviva mean: around 90%, my score: 100%
Midterm mean: around 40/100, my score: 66/100
Final mean: around 61/100, my score: 86/100
Using scheme 2: 87.4/100

The final exam is a lot easier than the midterm exam.
Absolute grading. With 5 marks interval for each sub-grade.
>=95% A+
90%-95% A
85%-90% A-
then B range, C range, etc.
The passing mark is around 30% (not sure)

Final letter grade: A-

For your reference, I got C- in Math 1013. So don't give up, try your best and you can get good grade.
reviews.comment_workload:
Not heavy.

One homework every week, using Integral calculator allows you to finish some homework within 30 mins.

But for those homework testing on convergence/divergence, Taylor/Power/Maclaurin series, you have to do it yourself. Personally, I spent 3 hours doing each of them as I didn't learn anything before the examinations.

Make sure to revise before exams. All the effort you have put into this course would eventually pay off.

reviews.author: hokim147
reviews.comment_content: Content is normal and useful. Actually, it is easier than MATH1013. Final is easy too as it is really similar to the previous exam.
reviews.comment_teaching: Even he knows I am not from his class, I can still get help. He will give a favor to all students.
reviews.comment_grading: Absolute grading. One MC can make a big different to your grade. I got A in my final exam as I answered 2 mc wrongly. Therefore, getting A+ is really difficult since you  are only allowed to get one mistake.
reviews.comment_workload: Just homework and one final. Nothing else.

reviews.author: kjyu
reviews.comment_content: Content is just more on calculus, but much demanding than MATH1012. If MATH 1012 is a 4 credit course, then MATH1014 should be an 8 credit course rather than a 3 credit course. As for what is taught in this course, just refer to the description provided by course catalog. Just keep in mind that this course is quite demanding and you might need to read the textbook for some challenging contents such as Taylor Series.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Jin is really good at encouraging his students to participate in his class. He is very welcome to answer your questions, so don't be shy to ask any if you want. The TA is the best TA I've ever met. He always emphasizes on the important points which may appear on the exams. Both the TA and the Professor has good English pronunciation as well as good patience. If your tutorial is taught by a horrible, be sure to ask your friend who enrolled in Walter's tutorials for some tutorial contents on his webpage.
reviews.comment_grading: It will take some effort to get a good grade in this course. The grading policy is 20% for assignment and 80% for final exam. We used class viva to submit our assignments and we can submit it as many times we want. So it's important to get full marks in assignments.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is quite high since the content is troublesome. However, it's better than the courses that require you to write essays and do presentations. In this course, the only thing you have to do is to study and practice some math problems, that's it.

reviews.author: jzhoubm
reviews.title: Fundamental calculus course
reviews.comment_content: Contents are basic and easy. If you want to challenge yourself or simply want to dig deeper into calculus, MATH1024 is definitely a better choice. However, If you just want to learn basic calculus skills, this course is enough.
reviews.comment_teaching: Teaching is quite good. The instructor will follow the lecture notes and state the theorems and proofs clearly. There were also a lot of materials for students to practice with. I recommend the calculus textbook Tomas Calculus, which can play a role as supplement. But generally speaking, if you listen clearly to the instructor, you will get a good hang of basic calculus.
reviews.comment_grading:
grading is good
My midterm and final score are all around mean+sd, and the final grade is A-. Many of my friends got A range.
reviews.comment_workload: workload is very small. I did no more than do homework, which did not take long, and review the lecture notes the day before midterm and final. I also skipped almost all the lectures.  As I stated in the content section, the contents are basic and easy. The course should not take you a lot of time.

reviews.author: Leon H
reviews.title: Good Grade
reviews.comment_content:
Basic calculus, mostly focus on integration

- Review of definite integrals and the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus
- Area of a region between curves, volume by slicing and cylindrical shells
- Length of curves, surface area, work, average value of a function
- Integration by parts, trigonometric integrals, trigonometric substitutions, polar coordinates and calculus, partial fractions
- Numerical integration, improper integrals
- Sequences and infinite series, divergence and integral, ratio, root and comparison tests, alternating series
- Taylor polynomials, power series and Taylor series
- Vectors in two and three dimensions, dot products, cross product

reviews.author: Finger_ha
reviews.title: Don't take it if it is not a compulsory course for your major or you did take M2
reviews.comment_content:
Difficult, difficult and difficult
I didn't take M2 during my senior grades of secondary school study, the whole course was so difficult for me to understand.
Although you might be able to understand part of the things, you need to put so much effort on it, especially for those who don't have calculus background.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Jin did try to carry examples to explain the things, though he sometimes forgot how to calculate some of the questions, he had been being so helpful in terms of helping the students to deal with the problems.
But, the teaching was quite boring I have to say, so he is definitely not the worst person to teach this course, but not the best one.
reviews.comment_grading:
Absolute grading, so your effort could control the most part of the grade besides the difficulty of the exam papers.

Webwork: 15%
Mid-term exam: 35%
Final exam: 50%
Bonus quizes: 4 x 2% -> 8% in total.

If you want to get an A-/A/A+, do remember to work on the quizzes.
If you just want to get a D/C-, you should also participate in the quizzes as they could probably save your life. Won't be too difficult if you want to get a D even if you didn't have any calculus background like me, as long as you finished all webworks (15%) and the bonus quizzes (8%), also, try to pay maximum effort for the mid term, as if will always be easier than the final one.
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload was not tough, 10 webworks in 13 weeks, just try to start working on them as soon as they were posted and mot waiting till the last minute and you will be fine. (You could also seek help from yahoo answers and symbolab/Wolfram or even ask for sources from you schoolmates)

1 mid-term exam (after ~6 weeks of teaching) and 1 final exam (during exam period). Bonus quizzes would be available around 3-4 weeks before the semester finished.

reviews.author: aneagonh
reviews.title: Super good grade math course in UST
reviews.comment_content:
Week 1 Review of definite integrals and the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, area between curves.
Week 2 Volumes by cross-sections, volumes by cylindrical shells.
Week 3 Work, average value of a function, arc length.
Week 4 Area of a surface of revolution, integration by parts.
Week 5 Trigonometric integrals, trigonometric substitution.
Week 6 Polar coordinates and calculus, partial fractions, summary of integration techniques.
Week 7 Approximation integration, improper integrals.
Week 8 Infinite sequences and series, integral test.
Week 9 Comparison tests, alternating series, absolute convergence, ratio and root tests
Week 10 Power series, represention of functions as power series .
Week 11 Taylor and Maclaurin series, applications of Taylor polynomials.
Week 12 Two and three dimensional coordinate systems, vectors.
Week 13 Dot product, cross product.

reviews.comment_teaching:

Though I can get A in LANG, you cannot fully understand what she says.
Other teachers use simple words to describe and explain. She uses(I think she only knows terms in English so uses it naturally) terminology that you need to look up for.
In a nutshell, she teaches Soviet Union content in an American way.

Btw, she spends 50% of her time doing inductions that never will be examed.

Bad for A students to get A +.

Aced the course. Go figure.

To be honest I don’t understand why people are always bitching about this course. I only got 5* in DSE, never studied M2 but I never think that this course is hard. The questions in homework are literally the same as the ones talked on class and the question type for the exams have been the same for the past decade. It’s impossible to not get above 70% if you have actually at least watched the recording. And the people complaining about the mid term are just straight up stupid. Maybe if instead of wasting your time after the exam you should work on it BEFORE it. And how the hell can you not at least get full marks with your homework there literally an ENTIRE DEPARTMENT TO HELP.
reviews.comment_workload: About 1 piece of homework every two weeks. Sadly not too much past papers or additional practice was provided so you would definitely need to work on finding sources.

reviews.author: Yu kaiwen
reviews.title: Math 1014
reviews.comment_content: The content is not that difficult to understand as long as you listen to the lectures and tutorials on time. And if you learn M2 in the HKDSE well, not so difficult.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I love the notes of Guibo. It is very clear and convenient to review.
No class attendence is needed (online mode).
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is not bad. But it is not easy to get a good score. I remember that the mean of midt is 48/100. And the grading accessment is as followed:

10% by online homework
(https://www.classviva.org (Links to an external site.))
35% by the midterm exam                             
55% by final exam

The grading is assigned based on all students' performance in assessment tasks, not absolute grade.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is ok, not that much: One midterm, one final and ten homework (Each one with 12-15 questions, very similar to MATH1013).

reviews.title: A class depends on your own calculation ablility
reviews.comment_content: It introduced many useful skills for integral. And these skills may not be mastered easily by oneself. But the limit part seems not so useful.
reviews.comment_teaching: The instructor will give many practice in class. But the content may be boring. So maybe it is more based on yourselves to review class notes.

reviews.author: SamuelLee
reviews.title: Content is OK but exams are another world
reviews.comment_content: It is calculus, mainly integration. After the midterm, there are series and the last 3 lectures are about vectors.
reviews.comment_teaching:
He has passion in maths and teaches quite well but he keeps making mistakes on the lectures. A lot of other students skipped almost every lecture.
However, at least he allowed us to see the midterm and final exam papers after the scores are released.
The tutorial is quite useful as Tommy explains how to solve different problems clearly, and some even came up in the exams.
reviews.comment_grading:
10/11 assignments via Webwork count to 15% of our grade.
The exams are open book and HKEAA approved calculators allowed.
The midterm exam (worth 25%) is moderately hard (7/10), especially for the long questions. (mean 34/70, sd 17). The final (worth 60%) is so difficult and the mean is very low. I had to guess two MCs. Mean was 39.xx and total mean was 48.xx, after 3(!) Updates.
I got +0.9sd and still got B! The grading is horrible!
reviews.comment_workload: Still reasonable if you don't expect your grade to be high, but if you want to do better, you need to do the extra webwork exercises, tutorial questions and textbook exercises. You can visit MSC if you need help.

reviews.author: lam814
reviews.comment_content: Well, just like CALCULUS. From sequence limit, to function limit, continuity, differentiation, Taylor series, and so on. In a typical curriculum, there no much thing to say.
reviews.comment_teaching: Skipped lectures, go read online tutorials.
reviews.comment_grading:
The 1014 final was on the 18th of May, 2016. It was also the day of the COMP2711 final.

Needless to say, the 18th of May was Judgement Day.

With each minute that passed in the exam hall, I could see fire rain down from the heavens and smite the poor souls, one by one. Given the conditions of the exam, it is highly unlikely that anyone would pass. I knew for a fact that I would fail. But I didn't.

Why?

There is only one possible explanation.

Ten days after the final exam and a few days before results were released, a divine tradegy occurred.

He died.
Almost noone noticed at first.
Reading the news gave me shivers.
After a while, I felt different.
My soul felt cleansed, my mind clear.
Boys and girls seemed worriless and carefree.
Everyone seemed.. purified.

He died for our sins. I will be forever grateful.

Rest in peace, our beloved savior.
reviews.comment_workload: one hw/wk

reviews.author: Yichen
reviews.title: 必修嘛，龟好不到哪去
reviews.comment_content: 就是一些基础的微积分，第一个月跟高中学的微积分差不多。
reviews.comment_teaching: 老师讲的很耐心，但是由于网课，上课体验不是非常良好。老师上课缺少回应，有点尴尬
reviews.comment_grading: grading还可以。但考试比重比较大。期末考试会比期中考试难不少,但是如果认真准备的话题目难度都不大。考试的话SD会非常大，有一部分原因是据我所知，这次期末考试cheating比较严重，所以我觉得B+比较容易，A range不算特别好。Spring的成绩一般比Fall的难拿，高考生大多都在spring上。

reviews.author: Sfvpcwl
reviews.title: Not as difficult as you may think
reviews.comment_content:
Basically an extension to MATH1013. Including integrals of areas and distances and basic techniques (trig, by part), as well as basics of math such as infinite series and complex numbers etc.

The content is useful for almost every math/physics/engineering course, and is very useful for understanding multivariable calculus.
reviews.comment_teaching:
He has a little bit of mainland accent, but it actually makes it easier to understand as I am from mainland as well.

Anyways, he is very passionate and wants the students to understand the mathematical concepts intuitively. Follow his lectures well and you should do well in the course.

Even if you fall a little bit behind, don't hesitate to send him an email. He is very responsive to student's needs.
reviews.comment_grading:
No attendance + Absolute grading

HW 100/100 & Midterm 80/100
Final: Not yet released (But i am confident to get A range in this course)

1/6 Updates: Easy A+ for 96%, I had some minor mistakes just to ensure TA are really marking. But the course is so forgiving and I can't imagine how people get any grade below A. Seriously? :D

p.s. GaoKao is much more difficult, I wish i had DSE instead.

In this semester, there are a lot of students who complain about the difficulty of the mid term exam (30/100 is the mean). Well actually, in my humble opinion, it is because they don't have a sound mathematical foundation plus they don't study nor complete exercises. To be honest they totally deserved it as I think the difficulty is fair compared to GaoKao in mainland.

This is not only my opinion, TKL also said the students did not work hard in the mid term.
reviews.comment_workload:
Fine if you have some mathematical background. If you can complete the assignments on your own, there should be no problem for your mid term and final.

If not, grab some from youtube channels from good content creators.

There are no excuses apart from laziness.

reviews.author: GoodgradeKid
reviews.title: Best math course for year 1 students
reviews.comment_content:
Basically, Calculus 2 but just a little bit harder. MATH 1012/3 is more complicated than this course trust me.

Syllabus:
•Area of a region between curves, volume by slicing and cylindrical shells.
•Length of curves, surface area, work, the average value of a function.
•Integration by parts, trigonometric integrals,  trigonometric  substitutions, polar  coordinates  and  calculus, partial fractions.
•Numerical integration, improper integrals.
•Sequences and infinite series, divergence and integral,ratio, root and comparison tests, alternating series.
•Taylor polynomials, power series and Taylor series.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Hu is really passionate in teaching maths. He uses a whiteboard and doesn't upload notes, but I think a student should write down their notes by themselves in order to develop a stronger conceptual understanding.
reviews.comment_grading:
Absolute grading, no attendance.
HW: 100/100
Midterm: 89/100
Final: 97/100
reviews.comment_workload: One homework set per week which is basically an understanding test for that week's lectures, and it's not too difficult, might take you an hour or two.
